trans-unit.source: Stage a cloud service deployment (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Stage a cloud service deployment (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy your Azure application to a staging environment, then deploy to a production environment using Virtual IP (VIP) swap.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy your Azure application to a staging environment, then deploy to a production environment using Virtual IP (VIP) swap.

trans-unit.source: Staging an Application in Azure
trans-unit.target: Staging an Application in Azure

trans-unit.source: A packaged application can be deployed to the staging environment in
trans-unit.target: A packaged application can be deployed to the staging environment in

trans-unit.source: Azure to be tested before you move it to the production
trans-unit.target: Azure to be tested before you move it to the production

trans-unit.source: environment in which the application is accessible on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: environment in which the application is accessible on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: The
trans-unit.target: The

trans-unit.source: staging environment is exactly like the production environment, except
trans-unit.target: staging environment is exactly like the production environment, except

trans-unit.source: that you can only access the staged application with an obfuscated URL
trans-unit.target: that you can only access the staged application with an obfuscated URL

trans-unit.source: that is generated by Azure.
trans-unit.target: that is generated by Azure.

trans-unit.source: After you have verified that your
trans-unit.target: After you have verified that your

trans-unit.source: application is working correctly, it can be deployed to the production
trans-unit.target: application is working correctly, it can be deployed to the production

trans-unit.source: environment by performing a Virtual IP (VIP) swap.
trans-unit.target: environment by performing a Virtual IP (VIP) swap.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article only apply to node applications hosted as an Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article only apply to node applications hosted as an Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: This task includes the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This task includes the following steps:

trans-unit.target: [Step 1: Stage an Application]

trans-unit.source: [Step 2: Deploy an Application to Production by Swapping VIPs]
trans-unit.target: [Step 2: Deploy an Application to Production by Swapping VIPs]

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Stage an Application
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Stage an Application

trans-unit.source: This task covers how to stage an application by using the **Windows
trans-unit.target: This task covers how to stage an application by using the **Windows

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: When publishing a service, simply pass the -Slot parameter to
trans-unit.target: When publishing a service, simply pass the -Slot parameter to

trans-unit.source: the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Publish-AzureServiceProject -Slot staging
trans-unit.target: Publish-AzureServiceProject -Slot staging

trans-unit.source: Log on to the [Azure Management Portal] and select Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the [Azure Management Portal] and select Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: After the cloud service is created and the Staging column status has been updated to Running, click on the service name.
trans-unit.target: After the cloud service is created and the Staging column status has been updated to Running, click on the service name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>portal displaying a running service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>portal displaying a running service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Dashboard, and then select Staging.
trans-unit.target: Select the Dashboard, and then select Staging.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>cloud service dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>cloud service dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note the value in the Site URL entry to the right.
trans-unit.target: Note the value in the Site URL entry to the right.

trans-unit.source: The DNS name is an obfuscated internal ID that Azure generated.
trans-unit.target: The DNS name is an obfuscated internal ID that Azure generated.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>site url</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>site url</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now you can verify that the application is working correctly in the staging environment by using the staging site URL.
trans-unit.target: Now you can verify that the application is working correctly in the staging environment by using the staging site URL.

trans-unit.target: For an upgrade scenario, in which the staged application is an upgraded

trans-unit.source: version of one that has already been deployed to production, you can
trans-unit.target: version of one that has already been deployed to production, you can

trans-unit.source: [upgrade the application in the production environment by swapping the
trans-unit.target: [upgrade the application in the production environment by swapping the

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Upgrade an Application in Production by Swapping VIPs
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Upgrade an Application in Production by Swapping VIPs

trans-unit.source: After you have verified the upgraded version of an application in the
trans-unit.target: After you have verified the upgraded version of an application in the

trans-unit.source: staging environment, you can quickly make it available in production by
trans-unit.target: staging environment, you can quickly make it available in production by

trans-unit.source: swapping the virtual IPs (VIPs) of the staging and production
trans-unit.target: swapping the virtual IPs (VIPs) of the staging and production

trans-unit.source: environments.
trans-unit.target: environments.

trans-unit.source: This step assumes that you have already deployed an
trans-unit.target: This step assumes that you have already deployed an

trans-unit.source: application to production and staged the upgraded version of the
trans-unit.target: application to production and staged the upgraded version of the

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Management Portal],
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Management Portal],

trans-unit.source: click Cloud Services and then select the service name.
trans-unit.target: click Cloud Services and then select the service name.

trans-unit.source: From the Dashboard, select Staging, and then click Swap at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: From the Dashboard, select Staging, and then click Swap at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: This opens the VIP Swap
trans-unit.target: This opens the VIP Swap

trans-unit.source: dialog.
trans-unit.target: dialog.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>vip swap dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>vip swap dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Review the information, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Review the information, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: The two deployments
trans-unit.target: The two deployments

trans-unit.source: begin updating as the staging deployment switches to production and
trans-unit.target: begin updating as the staging deployment switches to production and

trans-unit.source: the production deployment switches to staging.
trans-unit.target: the production deployment switches to staging.

trans-unit.source: You have successfully staged a deployment and upgraded a production
trans-unit.target: You have successfully staged a deployment and upgraded a production

trans-unit.source: deployment by swapping VIPs with the deployment in staging.
trans-unit.target: deployment by swapping VIPs with the deployment in staging.
